column1: #Text=In addition to filtering based on the amplitude of the wavelet coefficients as described above, it may be desired to instead or in addition filter out wavelet coefficients representing certain scales where unimportant signal information is represented.
#Text=For example, the wavelet coefficients representing the widest wavelets may be set to zero to eliminate the contributions of the widest scale attributes of the signal.
#Text=Other sets of wavelet coefficients representing a particular scale may be zeroed out to eliminate the contributions, depending on the application desired.

#Text=In the 48 point Haar wavelet transform described above, for example, the last 3 wavelet coefficients which correspond to the widest wavelets and which do not provide significant signal discrimination may be set to 0 and thereby filtered out.
#Text=Alternatives to this method may utilize all wavelet coefficients, or may filter out different sets corresponding to different scales in order to optimize discrimination performance.
#Text=As mentioned previously, the DWT can be defined using other wavelet functions.
#Text=In many instances, the wavelet functions are chosen to be non-zero for some finite duration in order to maintain the time-localization property of the DWT.

#Text=Additional constraints on the shape of the wavelet functions are generally used so that good frequency resolution can be achieved, especially when the DWT is used for time-frequency signal analysis.
#Text=Compared to other wavelet functions, the Haar function does not provide very good time-frequency localization.
#Text=However, as will be shown in below, the Haar wavelet does have the ability to localize salient time-domain features of EGM waveforms for purposes of discriminating waveforms.
#Text=For this application, the relatively poor frequency localization does not seem to affect discrimination performance.
#Text=Wavelet Based EGM Morphology Discrimination Algorithm--First Embodiment
